quoteFirst: Four editions of "Writing for the Press" have been required. For each edition the work has been revised and enlarged, so that it has grown from
quoteLast: ty-six pages,--yet, it is believed, without the addition of a useless sentence. New matter has been added partly to make the book more useful to newspaper writers, and partly to bring within its scope all other writers.
title: Methods of Authors
author: Erichsen, Hugo, 1860-1944

quoteFirst: Burt's Creek after G. Burt, Esquire, of Adelaide. Started at
quoteLast: on course of 90 degrees; at half a mile crossed large rocky creek from the south with boulders of lava in its bed; there was lava also at starting; a continuation of rough lava country for three miles; bad travelling. At three and three-quarter miles crossed strong running river or creek, granite bed; fish; with oaks, current to northward.
title: McKinlay's Journal of Exploration in the Interior of Australia
author: McKinlay, John, 1819-1872

quoteLast: ty-Two! A full half-century of story! And now, our Century's end in view. May's back once more in vernal glory, And with it brings your Jubilee, (_Punch_ came to his one year before you!) "Many Returns," Ma'am, may you see, And honoured be the hour that bore you!
title: Punch, or the London Charivari, Volume 102, May 21, 1892
author: Various

title: The Practical Book of Oriental Rugs

quoteFirst: On the front of the plants, 24 leaves were marked with thread, some of which had their blades horizontal, but the greater number were inclined at about 45°, beneath the horizon; at night all these, without exception, became vertical. Early on the following morning (4th) they reassumed their former positions, and at night again became vertical. On the 5th the shutters were opened at 6.15 A.M., and by
quoteLast: , after the leaves had been illuminated for 2 h. 3 m. and had acquired their diurnal position, they were placed in a dark cupboard. They were looked at twice during the day and thrice in the evening, the last time at 10.30 P.M., and not one had become vertical.
title: The Power of Movement in Plants
author: Darwin, Charles, 1809-1882; Darwin, Francis, Sir, 1848-1925

quoteLast: and now it was three. It was all the progress they could hope for, and much of it was due to Cameron. He had misjudged the doctor's reasons for staying and he was thankful he could admit it to himself.
title: Address: Centauri
author: Wallace, F. L. (Floyd L.), 1915-2004; Wood, Wallace, 1927-1981 [Illustrator]
